Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

nodes.body: :v: sgouezel can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

bors r+
Thanks for the review!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8812309518/job/24187749725)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8812309518/job/24187749195)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8812309518/job/24187749365)

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem ContinuousLinearEquiv.integrable_comp_iff {φ : α → H} (L : H ≃L[𝕜] E) :
```

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem LinearIsometryEquiv.integrable_comp_iff {φ : α → H} (L : H ≃ₗᵢ[𝕜] E) :
```

Given that the constants don't appear in the conclusion, isn't this a job for `Bornology.IsBounded`? For example:
```lean
open Bornology Set in
example {f : D → E} :
    IsBounded (range f) ↔ (∃ C₁, ∀ x, ‖f x‖ ≤ C₁) := by
  rw [isBounded_iff_forall_norm_le]
  exact exists_congr fun C ↦ by simp
```

Although on second thought, perhaps it might be out of style with the rest of this file (where you need more general comparison results which cannot simply be stated in the language of `IsBounded`). I guess the root cause is that `Function.HasTemperateGrowth` is stated as a comparison of the size rather than a boundedness statement.

With that in mind, I'll leave it to your discretion.

The real interesting statement is the next lemma, for explicit bounds on the integrals. The current lemma is just an auxiliary statement, to be able to apply the next one (as there are often integrability side conditions). So, I feel it's important that the two lemmas are phrased with exactly the same set of assumptions. Let me add a comment on this.
A final thought is that this would yield a fairly neat statement if expressed in the language of bounded functions since all the constants could be dropped.
Not sure this would make things easier to manage, as one would need to coerce the relevant functions to spaces of bounded functions.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: more integrability statements for iterated derivatives of Schwartz functions

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Fourier transform as a continuous linear equiv on Schwartz space
